artist: Artist: Utagawa Hiroshige; Publisher: Sakanaya Eikichi
creditline: Gift of John and Ida Davies
description: overhead view of zigzagging river with two rowboats in foreground; yellow zigzagging path along water's edge with some pink blossoming trees and walking figures; banners along path in middle ground; building in a grove of trees at left center; flying birds in a zigzag in URQ; salmon color at horizon, purple color at top in sky
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From One Hundred Famous Views of Edo (Meisho Edo hyakkei 名所江戸百景)
text: One Hundred Famous Views of Edo is from the last great landscape series designed by Utagawa Hiroshige. This print was the thirty-first in the series and depicts the cherry-tree lined approach to Azuma Shrine, in what is now eastern Tokyo. The shrine is known for a tree with a split trunk, the titular “entwined camphor,” which can be seen on the shrine’s grounds.
title: Azuma Shrine and the Entwined Camphor
